newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: Court says EU trade rules preclude national labels.
newsitem.headline: Court says EU trade rules preclude national labels.

text.p: The European Court of Justice said on Wednesday that EU intra-community trade rules preclude abstract French labeling laws restricting the use of the term "mountain" on meat products.

The European Union has adopted its own set of procedures to grant special labeling on products to designate regional origin. To qualify for geographic indication or origin, EU rules require that products originate from a specific area and are processed or prepared there.
An application for product specification must include details manifesting a real link with a certain geographical environment or origin, not simply any mountainous area.
The court threw out the French law as restrictive of trade between member states on the basis of the treaty, and not the EU legislation harmonising designation of origin rules.
"The French legislation discriminates as it reserves use of the description mountain to products manufactured on national territory and made from domestic raw materials," the court said.
"The treaty covers all trading rules enacted by member states which are capable of hindering, directly or indirectly, acutally or potentially, intracommunity trade."
Reference for a preliminary ruling by the French Cour de Cassation in the criminal proceedings against
Jacque Pistre, Michele Barthes, Yves Milhau, Didier Obertis

on the interpretation of article 2 of Council regulation No 2081/92 on the protection of geographical indications and designations of origin for agricultural products and foodstuffs (OJ 1992 L 208, p.1) and of EC Treaty articles 30 and 36

1. Council regulation No 2081/92 on the protection of geographical indications and designations of origin for agricultural products and foodstuffs does not preclude application of domestic rules, such as those contained in article 34 of Law No 85-30 and Decree No 88-194 which lay down the conditions governing the use of the description "mountain" in relation to agricultural products and foodstuffs.

2. EC Treaty article 30 precludes application of domestic rules, such as those laid down in article 34 of Law No 85-30 and Decree No 88-194, which restrict use of the description "mountain" to products manufactured on national territory and prepared from domestic raw materials.
